itemDescription: English artist and children's book illustrator (1858-1932)

wikipedia_page.main: Gordon Frederick Browne  (15 April 1858 – 27 May 1932) was an English artist and a prolific illustrator of children's books in the late 19th century and early 20th century. He was a meticulous craftsman and went to a great deal of effort to ensure that his illustrations were accurate. He illustrated six or seven books a year in addition to a huge volume of magazine illustration.

response: In 1964 he participated in Young Commonwealth Painters at Whitechapel Gallery, London, which also included other New Zealand painters Ralph Hotere, Edward "Ted" Bullmore, and Gordon Browne.  After graduating with a Bachelor of Arts with honours, he taught at schools of art in London before returning to New Zealand in 1968.
Gordon Browne illustrated 'The Man Upstairs",McIlvaine (1990), p. 182, D.133.5. H. M. Brock illustrated "Deep Waters",McIlvaine (1990), p. 182, D133.7.

link_mentions.page: The Fifth Form at St. Dominic's
response: The Fifth Form at St. Dominic's (published 1881) is the best known of the school stories by the late nineteenth century author Talbot Baines Reed. The stories as well as the book were written for the Boy's Own Paper and published by the Religious Tract Society, with illustrations by Gordon Browne. It was adapted into the 1921 film of the same name.

link_mentions.page: List of 19th-century British children's literature illustrators

response: Prince Prigio is a literary and comic fairy tale written by Andrew Lang in 1889 and illustrated by Gordon Browne.  It draws in Lang's folklorist background for many tropes.
*Gordon Browne (1858–1932), English artist and children's book illustrator
* "The Pavilion on the Links", illustrated by Gordon Browne. 1913.
